content.html:
I'm not a big fan of option 4.

I like option 3. I would argue that we can make the API for this not that bad. We can put the Vertex value first in the std::pair and the bool second to be consistent with the sdf::Element::Get function.

Here are additional usage examples:

std::reference_wrapper<Vertex<V>> vertex;
bool result;

std::tie(vertex, result) = graph.AddVertex(0, "0");

std::reference_wrapper<Vertex<V>> vertex;

std::tie(vertex, std::ignore) = graph.AddVertex(0, "0");

auto vertex = std::get<0>(graph.AddVertex(0, "0"));
auto result = std::get<1>(graph.AddVertex(1, "1"));

content.raw: Looks like Merriam-Webster says both are okay.
content.html: Looks like Merriam-Webster says both are okay.

update.description: A class to create directed graphs.
update.title: Graph

content.html:
I've been doing some research based on the feedback and before going too far I'd like to describe some of the API options:

For the shake of simplicity, let's focus on a function that creates a vertex and returns some handler (pointer, reference, etc.) to the vertex created. We can extrapolate the conclusions to the rest of the functions.

1. std::shared_ptr (current approach):

Function signature: 

std::shared_ptr<Vertex<V>> AddVertex(...);

How to use it: 

auto v0 = graph.AddVertex(0, "0");
if (v0)
  std::cout << v0->Name();

Pros:

  • If the vertex cannot be created (e.g.: incorrect Id) you can return nullptr.
  • If needed, it's possible to return a std::vector of std::shared_ptr (e.g.: Vertexes() function).

Cons:

  • We're sharing ownership of the vertex with the client which we shouldn't.
  • As all pointers, if used incorrectly can lead to a segfault.

2. Reference to a vertex:

Function signature: 

Vertex<V>& AddVertex(...);

How to use it: 

auto v0 = graph.AddVertex(0, "0");
std::cout << v0.Name();

Pros:

  • No risk of segfault.
  • Nice API.

Cons:

  • There's no way to notify that the vertex cannot be created (e.g.: incorrect Id), we have to return a reference to an actual vertex (and maybe we don't have any).
  • It's not possible to return a std::vector of std::shared_ptr (e.g.: Vertexes() function).

3. std::reference_wrapper<Vertex<V>>: I discover std::reference_wrapper doing this research. Apparently is a wrapper that allows to copy references and store them in STL containers.

Function signature: 

std::pair<bool, std::reference_wrapper<Vertex<V>>> AddVertex(...);

How to use it: 

auto res = graph.AddVertex(0, "0");
if (res.first)
{
  auto v = res.second.get();
  std::cout << v0.Name();
}

Pros:

  • If needed, it's possible to return a std::vector of std::reference_wrapper.
  • No pointers, users cannot use them wrong.

Cons:

  • Not so nice API.
  • We can notify whether the vertex was created with the first boolean element of the returned tuple. However, we still need to return a reference to some vertex.

4. std::weak_ptr:

Function signature: 

std::weak_ptr<Vertex<V>> AddVertex(...);

How to use it: 

auto wpV0 = graph.AddVertex(0, "0");
auto v0 = wpV0.lock();
if (v0)
{
  std::cout << v0->Name();
}

Pros:

  • If the vertex cannot be created (e.g.: incorrect Id) you can return nullptr.
  • If needed, it's possible to return a std::vector of std::weak_ptr (e.g.: Vertexes() function).

Cons:

  • Slightly uglier API.
  • As all pointers, if used incorrectly can lead to a segfault.

@nkoenig and @chapulina suggested to use references but there are a few issues. I feel that option (4) is the one that fits better although I confess that the API is not my favorite. Opinions or other comments/ideas?

content.raw: Sorry, you are right.
content.html: Sorry, you are right.

I think this function can be slightly improved. The at function of std::map can throw an exception. There are checks in this function to make sure the element exists before calling at, but .... safety first.

The following also only performs one lookup.

auto iter = this->ids.find(_id);
if (iter == this->ids.end())
  return nullptr;

return iter->second;

content.raw: I can be wrong but I don't think C++ allows to return a vector of references.
content.html: I can be wrong but I don't think C++ allows to return a vector of references.

content.raw: Return a vector of references?
content.html: Return a vector of references?

content.raw: Return a reference?
content.html: Return a reference?

content.raw:
I was a little confused by the meaning of adjacent, given the documentation I'd expect that to include both incoming and outgoing vertexes. But looking at the tests the code is only returning the outgoing ones.

So I took a 2 min [crash course](http://www.slideshare.net/Abrish06/graph-48747573) on graph theory sponsored by google and my current understanding is:

![graph.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/dg5enz/images/1250468184-graph.png)

* vertex 0 is adjacent **to** 1
* vertex 1 is adjacent **from** 0
* vertex 0 is adjacent (to + from) 1 and 3
* edge (0->1) is incident **to** vertex 1
* edge (0->1) is incident **from** vertex 0
* edge (0->1) is incident (to + from) vertexes 0 and 1
content.html:
I was a little confused by the meaning of adjacent, given the documentation I'd expect that to include both incoming and outgoing vertexes. But looking at the tests the code is only returning the outgoing ones.

So I took a 2 min crash course on graph theory sponsored by google and my current understanding is:

  • vertex 0 is adjacent to 1
  • vertex 1 is adjacent from 0
  • vertex 0 is adjacent (to + from) 1 and 3
  • edge (0->1) is incident to vertex 1
  • edge (0->1) is incident from vertex 0
  • edge (0->1) is incident (to + from) vertexes 0 and 1

content.raw: Can `_tail` and `_head` be references?
content.html: Can _tail and _head be references?

content.raw:
Can we return a reference to the `head` instead of a shared pointer? I don't believe we want to share ownership of `head` with the person that calls this function.

The same applied to `Tail()`.
content.html:
Can we return a reference to the head instead of a shared pointer? I don't believe we want to share ownership of head with the person that calls this function.

The same applied to Tail().

content.raw: Shouldn't this ID be automatically generated by Vertex, and not passed in as a parameter to the constructor?
content.html: Shouldn't this ID be automatically generated by Vertex, and not passed in as a parameter to the constructor?

Can the arguments be rearranged to place mandatory elements first? I'm thinking of the case when a user wants to construct a Vertex without data.

For example, in the future we may extend this class to support different constructors.

Vertex(_id);
Vertex(_id, _name);
Vertex(_id, _name, _data);

content.raw: Suggestion: call the class `DirectedGraph`, in case we want to support `UndirectedGraph`s in the future.
content.html: Suggestion: call the class DirectedGraph, in case we want to support UndirectedGraphs in the future.

content.raw: Besides this check, this test is the same as the test above. The name of the test `EdgesWithIDs` suggests that ids would be checked, but it looks like edges don't have ids.
content.html: Besides this check, this test is the same as the test above. The name of the test EdgesWithIDs suggests that ids would be checked, but it looks like edges don't have ids.

content.raw: Mention in the documentation that all edges connected to the vertex will be removed too?
content.html: Mention in the documentation that all edges connected to the vertex will be removed too?

content.raw:
Once an edge has been removed from a graph, there's no way to put it back there, right? 

An idea would be to return weak pointers rather than shared pointers. Once they're removed from the graph, they're destroyed. If anyone holding a weak pointer tries to access it in the future, they won't be able to. 

As I understand it, this would make it clear that who owns edges and vertexes and is responsible for their lifetime is the graph. Others can borrow them for a bit to peek at the information, but they don't share ownership.

I guess the only difference is that in your implementation, someone holding the pointer could still access the edge's data after the edge is removed.
content.html:
Once an edge has been removed from a graph, there's no way to put it back there, right?

An idea would be to return weak pointers rather than shared pointers. Once they're removed from the graph, they're destroyed. If anyone holding a weak pointer tries to access it in the future, they won't be able to.

As I understand it, this would make it clear that who owns edges and vertexes and is responsible for their lifetime is the graph. Others can borrow them for a bit to peek at the information, but they don't share ownership.

I guess the only difference is that in your implementation, someone holding the pointer could still access the edge's data after the edge is removed.

content.raw: Is it mentioned anywhere in the documentation that there can't be repeated edges? Maybe there could be two edges between the same vertexes but with different data?
content.html: Is it mentioned anywhere in the documentation that there can't be repeated edges? Maybe there could be two edges between the same vertexes but with different data?
